segments.text: My name is Gabriel Katt and today is December 27th, 1983.
I'll be interviewing Joseph J. Sanchez, former managing director of General Motors of Brazil.
He is now general manager of Oldsmobile.
When did General Motors first expand overseas?
General Motors first started going overseas in the late teens and the very early 20s.
As an example, we've been in Brazil since 1926, Argentina since 1925, and Uruguay since 1926 also.
Was this pretty similar to what was happening in other large corporations?
I believe it was.
It was right after World War I and people were looking to the expanding markets outside of the United States.
We'd lost the isolationist influence as a result of World War I and people were ready to expand their markets.
What was produced?
In those markets at first, the initial installations were mostly assembly plants, installations that put together the parts as exported from the United States.

Passenger cars mainly, but the greater degree of emphasis given by the foreign governments, of course, were for trucks and commercials, which they felt would be more useful in developing their war-torn economies.
How do these overseas operations fit into the General Motors corporate structure?
Well, at that point in time, a separate organization was set up to handle them, which is still in existence.
It was called General Motors Overseas Operations, headquartered in New York City, not in Detroit, and handled as a separate division within the corporation.
Okay.
Since 1950, the automotive industry has been growing faster in underdeveloped countries than in developed countries.
What's caused this increased interest in the underdeveloped nations?
Well...

Again, since 1950, that's the tail end of World War II, and every one of those nations is interested in the development of its economy, which can best be done by industries such as the automotive industry, which are heavily weighted towards labor and technological development.
Okay.
What kind of restrictions do these governments place on companies interested in establishing plants in South America?
Well, the great majority of the South American countries said, if you want to participate in our markets, you've got to make an investment and establish an industry in our country.
Otherwise, we are not going to let you continue shipping your vehicles from your home plant into our country, draining off our foreign exchange without contributing anything to our development.
So what kind of incentives did these multinational corporations offer?
Well, the most important incentive, of course, was access to the market.
The second incentive was a set of legislation that permitted you to compete in those markets, make a profit, and remit those profits to your home office.
What kind of factors did Jim look at in deciding where to go, where to build and invest?
Pretty much the same factors that we look at in establishing any business.
The size of the market, the potential of the market,
economic studies that give us an indication as to where those markets are headed and whether the size of the market justifies the risk and the investment that we're placing in the country.
Quite a bit of emphasis is given to a forecast of political stability, although that lately has been very, very uncertain.
Okay.
What kind of benefits does a country receive from a multinational corporation's investment in that country, such as labor?
First and foremost, the capital investment that comes in.
which gives the country an aura of economic respectability and thereby enhances its ability to go out and borrow money from other sources.

In other words, the banking system looks more favorably upon a country that has a massive investment from a General Motors or a Ford or a General Electric than it would if it were strictly an underdeveloped nation without any of the private sector taking any of the risks.
The other investments, of course, are the jobs that are made available because of the establishment of the industry.

technical improvement in the preparation of their people, because they've got to be trained to do their job in an automotive plant, and the general positive impact on the balance of payments of their country.
Is there any cultural exchange that is offered by General Motors, for example?
Well, General Motors offers a cultural exchange that I guess could better be defined as an educational exchange.
As you know, we've got one of the finest universities in the United States, the General Motors Institute.
And in Brazil, for example, almost 200 of my executives in Brazil had attended General Motors Institute for at least one year, and most of them had been on a two-year program.
So in that sense, you've got a massive transfer of cultures through the educational system in the United States.
So these are already employed executives?
In most cases from overseas, they are employed executives or sons of existing General Motors dealers.
Okay, so is there any opportunity for maybe just extremely bright students to have that opportunity?

In two of the countries, Argentina and Brazil, and I believe in Venezuela also, we had a scholarship program for promising students, which enabled them to come up and complete their education here in the United States on a general scholarship.
Okay.
Does the federal government encourage or discourage investment and expansion overseas?
The federal government of the United States doesn't really encourage or discourage.

It encourages because it would like to continue improving the exports from the United States and thereby help in our balance of payments problem, but it doesn't do anything specific as far as offering incentives like many other countries do.
In other words, they don't offer special tax incentives like the Japanese do.
In general, it's just...
a moral encouragement to industry to get out and compete in those markets.
This hasn't changed any with the problems we're having now, say, with Japan and the competition there?
No, it's changed very little outside of the Overseas Investment Bank, which has some very, very stringent rules and really is not competitive in overseas markets.

The United States government does not assist in exporting from the United States other than through information services, but does not offer specific incentives, again, like tax incentives, like rebate incentives, like so many of the others that the other countries use around the world, Brazil and Japan particularly.
Do U.S. companies overseas get taxed twice, once by the host country and once by the U.S.?
No, not really.
I'm not an expert on tax matters, but
They don't get taxed twice.
They can deduct their foreign taxes from the United States taxes, so they only pay taxes once.
And I see what you're getting at.
In that sense, that is a benefit.
However, what I was thinking of was a corporate tax rate in the United States of 48% and a corporate tax rate in Japan on exports of 24%.
Yeah, I was thinking of it of a much more positive advantage as opposed to just avoiding a negative of double taxation.
Okay.
So what about the guarantee program?
Guarantee in what sense?
I guess it would affect oil companies mostly when a country is taken over or something and they start nationalizing all industry.
You can get political risk insurance for your foreign investment, and that's true.
That is a very definite benefit.
As a matter of fact, we had political risk insurance in Chile when our assembly plant was taken over by the Allende government in, I believe, right at the very early 70s, right around 1970.
And the insurance does cover you against the takeover of your facilities as a result of political upheaval.
I believe that that insurance is backed by the U.S. government, but I also believe a lot of private insurance companies are involved in it.
Okay.
How does the fact that a tremendous number of American corporations are building plants and expanding overseas affect the U.S. economic and labor situation?
Well, so far it's been proven that the more plants that are established overseas by United States companies, the more jobs are created in the United States.
a requirement for the establishment of those plants.
You need the technicians, you need the technology, you need the supervision.

Once the plant is established and producing a consumer product, which can be back shipped into the United States, that of course could have a negative impact on that particular industry for those particular products.
I think the biggest concern in not

allowing U.S. companies to establish overseas and export their products to the United States would be the very negative reaction from foreign governments which would then shut off other industries or other products.
For example, not allowing Japanese cars to come into the United States could create the problem of the Japanese not importing computers or
agricultural products or something in another line.
The labor unions generally are the most vocal about overseas investment.
Is there a lot of pressure by the labor unions directed at domestic companies to halt or slow down investment or change their policies overseas?
There is a lot of pressure, but naturally the majority of the pressure comes on the part of the unions on government in Washington.
You're right at the present time, as you probably know.

the unions are promoting what they call a local content law in the automotive industry, which would require an imported car into the United States to have a certain percentage of United States parts in the car before it could be imported, thereby, in the union's view, generating jobs for those industries that manufacture those parts.
This is very common around the world.
This is not an original idea.
In Brazil, for example, every vehicle produced in Brazil had to have 85%
Brazilian parts before it could be built and sold in the country, thereby guaranteeing local industry, local labor, and a tactic of an underdeveloped nation to continue protecting its jobs.
So that kind of pressure does exist.
The law has passed Congress at the present time.
It probably will not pass the Senate.
It will probably be rejected in the Senate.
And if it is not rejected in the Senate,
President Reagan has promised to veto it anyway, so it doesn't seem like it's going to prosper.
Is this due to auto industry pressure or counter-lobbying?
Well, do you mean the veto of the law?
Yeah.
No, I think the automotive industry has, in general... Now, let me be more specific.
Chrysler Corporation has come out in favor of such a law.
As a matter of fact, Lee Iacocca believes that it should be in existence, thereby defending U.S. jobs.
Both Ford and General Motors have adopted a very neutral attitude towards the law.

I think in our particular case, General Motors recognizes that that kind of legal restriction would probably only generate major problems for us in our other facilities around the world and would be of no immediate benefit to us.
Chrysler, on the other hand, like I say, does support it, so there is a split decision on the part of the industry.
And as far as I know, the only lobbying that's going on for that law
is in favor of the law on the part of Chrysler Corporation.
OK. What kind of integration is there with local industries as far as supplies and sales go?
In an overseas country?
Integration in the sense of the car manufacturer, like General Motors, being a partner with the suppliers, or we normally are not partners with our suppliers.
We do not invest capital in our suppliers
What we do do in most cases in these underdeveloped nations is we go to a supplier that has potential.
Let's take a metal bender somewhere in Uruguay that thinks he can perhaps manufacture a radiator.

We will go in there with our specifications, our designs, and our engineers, literally set him up in business, recommend the equipment he has to buy, give him the specifications of the radiators we will buy, loan him the money for his

initial investment in raw materials and inventory, promise him that we will buy the product once he manufactures it for us, prepay for the product before we even receive it, and in that way take somebody who's got no capital but has some budding talent and get him into the business and try to turn him into a reliable supplier over time.
So that it's almost a red cross of automotive suppliers in order to get some of these emerging nations started into the automotive business.
Okay.
How much of what's produced in the jam plants is exported?
In our overseas plants?
Well, in Latin America, relatively little.
In Brazil, in its biggest year, which was 1981, we produced about 230,000 cars and trucks, of which a little over 20,000 were exported.
So about 10% of our production was exported, and they were exported exclusively to other Latin American countries.
some African republics.
Atom opal in Germany is our largest exporter.
It produces about a million units a year of which it, and it absorbs perhaps around a half a million in the German market and the other half million is exported to the other European markets.
We do very little exporting of cars and trucks to the United States for a number of reasons.
One of which is that the most important of which is that U.S. legislation on the vehicle is both safety and
and pollution-type legislation virtually precludes the foreign-built cars that we make from coming back into the United States.
What about parts production?
Parts?
And being exported back to the States?
That we do quite a bit of.
In Mexico, for example, you've got a number of plants, border plants, that are set up according to regulations
Mexican legislation, which produced parts and are exported to the United States.
We have an extensive exchange.
And I must apologize because my experience of overseas, when I say overseas, I mean outside of North America.
I keep forgetting that Canada is an independent country.

nation on our northern border, quite a number of cars are produced in Canada and back shipped into the United States in accordance with the automotive trade agreement between the two countries where parts go to Canada, Canada makes the cars and then exports them back into the United States.
That whole exchange with Canada is very positive for the United States, both in balance of payments and in the efficiency of the use of facilities.
But excluding Canada from any of my comments, we do ship parts in here from Mexico.

uh including some engines we export engines from brazil into the united states we export some electrical components from singapore and hong kong and an extensive part shipment does go on from other countries back into the united states okay do any south american countries have labor unions or organizations like that oh they all do they all do are they as well organized as they are here as powerful
Depends on the country.
Argentina in 1972, the labor unions became so powerful that they became unwieldy.
They became so powerful that they literally brought the country to its knees with a power that was totally misused.
Brazil, on the other hand, has had labor unions for many, many years, and they have been relatively ineffective because the government did not allow them to exercise power.
the normal prerogatives as we know them here in the United States.
A labor union in Brazil, for example, until 1981 could only negotiate non-economic issues.

In other words, the government decided what the wage increases and what the benefits were going to be to the workers, and the union itself only could negotiate perhaps overtime legislation, perhaps vacation legislation.
items that were minor in the minds of the workers and thereby took away from the strength of that particular union.
So you've got unions at all levels and at all degrees of effectiveness.
What positions in a GM plant are filled by American employees?
Well, the obvious answer is those positions that can't be filled adequately by local employees.
Let me give you an example.
In Brazil, we had 23,000 people working in the company, and we had 18 Americans, U.S. employees, in the company.
And of those U.S. employees, eight of the 18 were in staff positions.
The other eight staff positions were filled by Brazilians.
The remainder of the Americans, the other ten,
The majority of them reported to Brazilians.
But there were technicians, technicians in the financial sense mostly.
We had five technicians from GMAC in the United States down there helping us run our finance company.
And we had three finance department technicians in the finance department, treasury and controller, in the money-raising aspects of the business.
But in general, our policy is that a Brazilian
should fill any position that he's qualified to fill.
We would rather have a Brazilian executive in the job than an American executive.
What do you mean by staff position?
Staff position?
There were 16 people on my staff, of which 10 were major department heads.
They headed up departments such as engineering, manufacturing, finance, reliability, sales,
Those are the major department heads.

And then there were another six positions that were the subsidiary ones, like the head of the finance company or the controller or the director of public relations or the director of government relations.
And those 16 people were my cadre, which met on a weekly basis to establish the policy for the company.
And of those 16...
half were Brazilian and half were Americans, not by design.
That's not part of a policy 50-50.
On the contrary, as I said before, the policy is, if we can at all do it, to have 100% Brazilians in the job.
Is the local employee restricted to promotion within plants in that country, or could he theoretically be transferred to the U.S.?
On the contrary, we encourage the same policy that we follow here in the United States, where we're encouraging Americans to take an overseas assignment
as part of their career development path.
And in overseas territories, we do the same thing with overseas employees.
We encourage Brazilians to take assignments outside of Brazil, just as we encourage Germans to take assignments outside of Germany to better prepare them for their careers in their own countries.
Is there any, let's see how to put this, how do American employees, I mean in America, react to having foreign bosses?
In their overseas assignments?
No, here.
Here in the United States?
Yeah, okay, the foreign manager in his overseas assignment to the States, for example.
You mean a Brazilian back to the United States?
How would the American react working for a Brazilian?
Yeah, is there ever any problem with that?
Never any real problem, and I hesitate to answer the question because there's always a little bit of differences in national ways of thinking
A Brazilian will focus on a problem a little bit different than an American.
And if the American or the Brazilian, it's vice versa, they reply.
If the American or the Brazilian doesn't recognize that that is the foreign way of doing things and that the man is very, very capable...
There is a little bit of a resentment and a feeling that perhaps the boss doesn't know as much as he should know.
In most cases, they recognize the fact that the man has been put in that job because he has the capability to handle it.
And once they get used to his techniques, his way of thinking, his way of approaching the job, we have no problems.
In general, with some exceptions like anything else in this world, but in general, it's been a very, very effective
way of training our people, both U.S. people overseas or overseas people in the United States.
Do many women rise to management or supervisory positions, or does this depend on the country in South America where a plant is located?
A lot of it depends on the country, but unfortunately, you know, women in the automotive business have not had the tremendous levels of success that they have in other industries, and
It's a little bit difficult to explain why that is.
I guess that so many of the success paths in our industry are up the sales side.
And it is very difficult for a woman to break into the automotive sales end of the business, going out around the country, calling on dealers as the men do.
It's been something that in Latin American countries has been very difficult for them to accept.
We had one woman in our management, out of our top management in Brazil,
of approximately 90 executives.
We had one woman that had achieved that level.
And fortunately, in the last five or six years, there were another five that were progressing to the point where I believe by 1984 or 5, they will also be joining the group.
So the process is accelerating, but it is substantially behind where it is in the United States.
Are there any minority employment problems in South American countries?
Broad question.
Very, very broad question.
I guess we could start off by asking the question, are there minorities in some of these countries?
And I guess there are, just like there are in the United States.
But, for example, a black, by virtue of the fact that there are so few of them, is very definitely a minority in Argentina and Chile, for example.
A black, on the other hand, is not a minority in Brazil by virtue of the fact that there are so many of them.

And there's been such a mixing of the races over the last 100 years in Brazil as opposed to the other countries so that Brazil does not feel that it has any kind of a racial problem, although blacks do have difficulty getting the same educational treatment and the same employment treatment, but Brazilians do not look upon them as minorities.
So, yes, in some countries you've got a minority problem,
black rising to the hierarchy of management in Argentina, for example, I believe is totally unknown.
Not so in Brazil, where national heroes, sporting heroes are black.
There have been political leaders that are blacks that are recognized as outstanding citizens by their own people.
So it varies from country to country.
The further north you get in South America, the less likely it is that the blacks are
considered minorities, and I'm saying this incorrectly, the further north you progress, the more integrated the blacks are into the economy and into the national life of their country.

The southern countries, by virtue of the fact of having received very few blacks originally, as a result of the slaves being brought over from Africa back in the 18th and 19th centuries, have very few blacks, and there they are minorities.
Chile, Argentina, for example.
And so are they discriminated against in that sense, whatever would constitute a minority?
I think you see discrimination in the same fashion that we had it in the United States 30 years ago, where it was covert discrimination more than overt discrimination.
And I guess I'm talking about that point in time when the signs stopped reading
sit in the back of the bus or for whites only in the northern cities.
That kind of discrimination I have not seen.
But the covert kind, I guess, is the more pernicious.
It's the one that when you look around an office, you don't see any black people in the office, or you don't see any women who are also minorities in a lot of these cases in the office.
You see only white males.
And
You ask yourself what has happened to the fabric of the country that has created this situation where only white males can sit in this job and 100 desk jobs and they're all white males.
There's not a single woman and not a single black.
And you trace it back and you find out that they're still not getting the same educational opportunities.
They're not getting the same advancement opportunities.
Now, in all of these countries, I think without exception, massive steps have been taken to correct this.
And I believe that the leader in doing all this has been the United States.

I think the United States' example of what we have gone through over the past 30 years in trying to correct the minority treatment situation has received such favorable press and such a spotlight of attention from the countries in Latin America that they themselves, whether they know it or not, are following our example.
Did the energy crisis in the early 70s have as profound an effect in South America as it did in the United States?
Oh, very much so, particularly in those countries that were
very strong net importers of petroleum products like Brazil, like Uruguay.
Uruguay imports 100% of its petroleum requirements.
Brazil was importing 85% of its requirements when the first crisis hit.
Terrible impact on the economies, particularly from the inflationary point of view, as their petroleum costs doubled, tripled, and quadrupled over a very short period of time.
So that the economies were caught totally unprepared, and I think
Some of the things you're seeing now in the Brazilian economy particularly and in the economy of an Uruguay and an Ecuador and a Chile are still the strong aftershocks of that energy crisis.
Their incredible inflation rate?
Yes.
They've never been able to bring it back down to manageable levels.
Once it achieved a level of 30 to 40 percent a year as a result of the energy shock, it just picked up momentum and swept on up from that level.
What kind of changes were implemented in car production in South America as a result of the crisis?
Well, the biggest change that took place as a result of the crisis was that the markets went into a stalemate position, into stagnation.
Markets fell off and the volume fell off sharply.
Brazil was the only one that adopted, after the second energy crisis in the late 70s, an alternate fuels program.
trying to develop the usage of alcohol in passenger car engines and thereby maintaining their industrial production at a high level regardless of what was happening outside with OPEC.
They were very successful with that program.
Today, over 95% of all the cars produced in Brazil have 100% ethyl alcohol engines.
And they themselves now have been able to produce
over 40% of their petroleum requirements and have cut down their dependency on outside petroleum sources substantially from where they were five and six years ago.
No other countries down there are following their lead?
No other countries following their lead, to my knowledge.
There have been interested nations.
South Africa, who finds itself isolated from the rest of the world.
Indonesia, who has the potential for...
producing the necessary sugar cane to generate sufficient alcohol in quantities that would make this feasible.
The Philippines finds themselves in the same situation.
But none of those countries has gotten it off the ground as yet, other than for a minor gasohol-type program, where 10% or less of the fuel pumped into your tank is alcohol combined with gasoline.
Brazil is the only one that had the land area.
had the necessary government conditions in place to overnight put a program of this dimension into effect and did it very, very successfully.
And General Motors and Ford, whoever else down there, were all involved in this?
All directly involved.
As a matter of fact, the first meetings that were held on this subject were
with the Minister of Industry in 1977, and I participated in those meetings, and we were given two years to get the program into effect to develop engines that ran 100% on alcohol.
We asked for three, we were given two, and the consequences were almost predictable.
We produced the original vehicles, and we had very serious quality and service problems with them, not having had sufficient time to test them adequately.
But by the end of the first year and a half of the program,
The engines were as reliable as the current gasoline engines had been once we'd taken out all of the potential for corrosion, which was the biggest problem we were having with the alcohol.
And we are now, Ford, General Motors, Volkswagen, Fiat, and Mercedes-Benz, who are the major five in Brazil, are now the world authorities on alcohol engines.
And we, in fact, General Motors Brazil, is the...
is the alcohol project center for General Motors Corporation in the world.
In other words, if anybody wants to know anything about alcohol engines, they consult us in Brazil instead of consulting the home office.
OK. General Motors spent 53 years in Argentina.
What caused them to withdraw in 78?
Oh, it was a combination of offense.
I was there in 1972 and 1973, two very difficult years when Juan Domingo Peron came back and was elected as president of the country.
Economic crisis after economic crisis, the Argentine economy riding its usual roller coaster of highs and lows.
And we at General Motors, in expectation of better times, had been waiting for those better times and had allowed our product lineup
to not to develop adequately and maintain a competitive position.

So that when 1979 rolled around and the Argentine government decided that perhaps they wanted to rationalize their industry and reduce the number of manufacturers in the country, we found ourselves with the necessity to make a massive investment of well over $100 million.
And the outlook was that that investment could never be recovered.
The market would never rise to a point that would make this a wise decision.

That, coupled with the government's desire to cut back on manufacturers and their refusal to assist any of the manufacturers with any of their problems, prompted us to say, well, this is as good a time as any, and we shut down the operation that we'd had in Argentina since 1926.
That's not the last comment on the situation, however.

A year ago, we went back in and started negotiating with a local company in Argentina, some kind of a joint venture whereby the local company could perhaps assemble our products for us in that country.
And I would not be surprised to see General Motors vehicles once again sold in Argentina inside of 24 months.
In the 60s in Chile, many locally owned auto companies went out of business or were taken over by foreign firms.
Why was that?
Well, in the 60s, you actually had two series of problems.
In the very early 60s, and I arrived in Chile on August 1, 1960, so I'm familiar with it.
The government wanted to develop its national industry, as I said at the beginning of this interview.
And they, at the same time, wanted to defend their national boundaries against their sworn enemy, Peru.

So they selected a city called Arica on the very northern tip of Chile and created a free zone and told everybody that they could establish automotive industries in the city of Arica on a no-duty basis, which would make it a very favorable competitor with the rest of the country, and put the legislation in place to make it happen.
However, they also insisted that they had to be national companies.

So at that point in time, Ford, which was about the only one that had maintained an investment in that country, closed up shop and the assembly plants in Arica were established by Chilean car dealers.

At the end of the decade, when Salvador Allende came in as president, Salvador Allende, as you know, was a socialist president and a great part of his cabinet were communists, decided to take over the major industries in the country.
And one of these was the General Motors plant.
By that time, we were back in the country.
In other words, the dealer had established the industry in 1964.
We had purchased it from him in 1969.
Allende took it away from us in 1971.
When Allende committed suicide in 1973, the new military government asked us to take it back.
We have taken it back.
We're now operating it.
So it's been a little bit of a roller coaster revolving door yo-yo type program in Chile over the last 20 years with

uh the chileans having difficulty making up their mind what they want the industry to do and general mode is trying to react to whatever new set of circumstances appeared on the horizon okay brazil has shown tremendous growth and development in the past years what role have multinational corporations and gm in specific played in this growth well the multinational corporations have played a key role in this growth the revolution took place in 1963
The legislation was put in place to encourage foreign investments by 1967-68, and General Motors was one of the first to make a large investment in the country to manufacture passenger cars.
We had been assembling vehicles since the middle 20s, as I mentioned before.
It wasn't just us.
It was a number of other major multinational corporations, including multinational corporations that manufacture parts.
And when we talk about multinational, let's not just think of U.S. corporations, but a lot of European corporations came in also.
Bosch came in, manufactured electrical equipment.
Fiat came in with its latest technology.
So that the backing of these multinational companies with its investment gave Brazil the needed capital
to put its vaunted economic miracle in place.

As you will recall, the Brazilian economy, until the second oil shock, was growing at a rate of 6% to 8% a year and was being called the economic miracle of the world because of its tremendous success.
Since then, of course, events have caught up with it, and it's no longer an economic miracle because people realize that they've done it all.
They've done a great part of it on borrowed funds that it appears cannot be repaid at an appropriate time.

But General Motors was a key part in this development, and during my years there since 1976, not unusual for a new investor to come to General Motors and ask to talk to us specifically on our experiences in the country with the government, what we thought of the future of the country, what we thought of doing business in Brazil, how we felt we were being treated.

make its decisions according to the recommendations it received from people like ourselves who had no political axe to grind and who apparently maintained a higher degree of credibility with new investors than a foreign government could.
So they played an extremely key and important role in the development of the country.
Does industry work in conjunction with the U.S. government in any aspect of U.S. foreign policy?
By industry, I mean American industry.
No, none.
As far as foreign policy is concerned, none.
We must follow, according to U.S. law, U.S. legislation.
For example, despite the fact that General Motors Brazil is a Brazilian company, we could not sell products

to any of those countries on the so-called United States blacklist, which is a very limited group of countries, but right now consists of North Korea, Cuba, I don't know, there's three others or thereabouts, but countries that the United States government felt were a threat to its security.
Russia and China, by the way, are not on that list, just to give you an idea of the specific nature of the list.
So we had to follow U.S. legislation.
But as far as influencing or assisting U.S. foreign policy, none of that went on specifically.
Okay.
Did you ever deal personally with any South American political figures?
Oh, yeah, on a constant basis.
See, you have to remember, for example, General Motors in Brazil was the fifth largest privately owned corporation in the country.
That would be like being the president or the chairman of Ford here in the United States.
And I had the same access to the Brazilian government
that the president of Ford would have to the United States government because of its importance to the national economy.
So I dealt with Salvador Allende in Chile when he was a senator before he became president.
I met him while he was president.
I've met the presidents and the cabinet members even more importantly because the cabinet members are the ones that established the industrial policy.
In Argentina, in Uruguay, in Brazil, in Venezuela, in every country that we're established, we are a very powerful force
from a world image point of view, it's very important for a government to say that General Motors has an operation in their country.
It gives them an international level of stability that they're very anxious to maintain.
And as a result, the contacts are continuous.
You talk about an image.
Well, so then a country is able to get, let's say, all the loans that Brazil got.
What's going to happen?
What can potentially happen when a country like Brazil right now can't pay back all that money?
I've read a lot of scenarios, and I was on the scene for quite a long time.

disaster scenario of course is that they don't pay declare a moratorium in the united states banking system collapses right uh i don't think that's going to happen at all i think what's going to happen is is a little bit of more of the same i think that the united that the banking system itself is to blame for a lot of what's happened uh i know personally people that were in brazil soliciting the brazilian government to take additional loans at very attractive
interest rates advantageous to the banking system at a point in time when Brazil, it was very, very clear that their balance of payments was not generating enough funds to pay off those debts.
The banking system has gotten much more cautious, much more realistic in releasing new loans, and Brazil finds itself in a position of over $90 billion in debt.
with just an interest amortization on that debt of $8 to $9 billion a year and a favorable balance of payments.
This year, it's going to be their most favorable year ever, and they'll probably have a favorable balance of payments of $7 billion.
So it's obvious that they can't even pay the interest on the loan, that they need new loans to continue paying the interest on the old loans.
And I think that's what's going to happen.
I think there's going to be a rescheduling of the debt, a stretching out of...

of the payment periods, perhaps a delay in the payment of the principal with a continuation of the payment of the interest, and some kind of an arrangement between the international banking system and the government that will allow the country to continue functioning and developing and allow the banks to continue to carry that debt and feel comfortable about eventually collecting it.
when nobody knows and nobody's too anxious to find out.
Okay, do U.S. executives overseas usually bring their families with them?
Yeah, always.
The executive that did not bring his family was the very obvious exception.
He was either separated or didn't have a family to bring.
As a matter of fact, we at General Motors encouraged our executives and almost insisted that they bring their families.
We felt that an executive with his family

could do a much better job because of the degree of stability that continuing family life provided them as opposed to being concerned about what mama was doing with the house in Connecticut or something.
Is there much social mixing with the local population or do the Americans tend to socialize with each other as happens in military bases quite often?
A difficult question to answer with just one answer.
Some Americans associate only with Americans and always will because they feel comfortable with something that they're very, very familiar with.
But the vast majority of them, us, associated with the local population.
Very, very close friends in the Brazilian, Argentine, Uruguayan, Chile community, in my case.
We had no problems with the language, liked the people, and discovered that that was really the way that we got a lot more out of the time that we spent in the country.
so that I would say the vast majority of Americans really make an effort to get out and mix with the local community.
So there isn't any problem in learning the language, or do, like in Europe, do most people speak English?

Well, that is a very serious problem, and there I blame the United States educational system for not insisting that everybody learn at least one foreign language while he's growing up, because my experience has been if you learn one, you can learn two.
But when you've learned a second language, you can learn a third language very easily.
If you've never learned any language except your own,
By the age of 40, it's almost impossible to learn a foreign language, and it is a problem.

And Americans have much more difficulty, in general, now there are very specific examples to the contrary, but in general, have much more difficulty learning a foreign language than most overseas people or foreigners.
And it is a problem in doing their jobs and in making themselves feel at home in a foreign country.
How many South American countries, well, many of them have unstable governments.
How does this affect the lifestyle of Americans overseas?
Well, the degree of instability, again, is relative.
In Brazil, for example, the government was very, very stable.
The lifestyle was totally free, no problems.
In 1972, 1973 in Argentina, the government was totally unstable.
It was a military government with a very strong degree of...
of terrorism, kidnapping, assassinations.
The president of Fiat was assassinated, for example.
Three executives, one American and two Argentine executives of the Ford Motor Company were assassinated.
It puts a lot of pressure on family life.
You become a lot more careful.
You live under constant security.
And it's a very, very nervous and trying times.
But I think most of the families that I knew came through
stronger than ever before as a result of their experiences.
Once you came through it, it was something that you could point to with pride for the rest of your life.
I've met people from those times since, and they're very, very proud of what happened to them there.
Okay.
Is terrorism or protest generally directed at the plant or company as a whole or at individual Americans?
